title: Extend spec %compiler syntax to accommodate binary, script, and data packages
body:
### Suggestion

Extend Spack's compiler spec syntax by a reserved value that accommodates packages that _do not need a compiler_. For concreteness (ahem), let me suggest:

```
%none
```

* Spack seems to lack the concept of compiler-less packages, but it would appear to sorely be needed, see below and #7550 for several examples.
* The reserved token is to have the property that ``foo%none`` satisfy a depency ``^foo%bar`` for an actual compiler.
* The ``%none`` "compiler" should be pre-defined. This may lead to interesting conundrums for bootstrapping.
* The concept is analogous to the ``noarch`` token in RPM packages, used to provide a single package that can be installed on different CPU architectures. Without ``noarch``, RPMs would have to be generated for each CPU architecture, equal in all aspects but metadata.

Alternative tokens could perhaps be ``%`` (empty content),  ``%*``, ``%null``. I would think, however, that these are either more difficult to handle or more difficult to grep for.   ``%nocomp`` is also possible but seems redundant when ``%`` is accepted and read as the spec mini-language's sigil for "compiler".  Spack's Python-ness might suggest ``%None`` but that can be terribly misleading in use and debugging, and is also difficult to grep for.

### Expected Result

Consider the ``intel-mkl`` package, which provides libraries for linear algebra and FFT. It is distributed by its vendor as a binary package and can by design be used with different compilers.

Assuming ``%none`` is implemented:

1. Do:
   ```
   spack install intel-mkl
   ```
   Appropriate settings in the ``package.py`` code should treat this as being identical to:
   ```
   spack install intel-mkl%none
   ```
2. Then:
   ```
   spack install foo%gcc   ^intel-mkl
   spack install foo%intel ^intel-mkl
   ```
   In both cases, the singular existing ``intel-mkl%none`` should be used.


### Actual Result

Leaving out ``%none``, the following happens:

1. ``spack install intel-mkl`` installs ``intel-mkl`` for Spack's default compiler (either``%gcc``, or the one configured first in ``packages.yaml`` under ``all:``, ``compiler:``). So far, so good – seemingly.

2. Regardless of Spack's default compiler, in at least one of the following commands _a second version_ of ``intel-mkl`` will be installed implicitly and likely unexpected by the user, just to match the compiler of the calling package ``foo``
   ```
   spack install foo%intel ^intel-mkl
   spack install foo%gcc   ^intel-mkl
   ```
   Moreover, the following would install _yet nother version_ of ``intel-mkl``:
   ```
   spack install foo%gcc@otherversion   ^intel-mkl
   ```

### Discussion

* It is already possible to qualify a dependence that uses a different compiler. E.g., assuming ``%gcc`` is the default, the following would work:

   ```
   spack install intel-mkl
   # installs as   intel-mkl%gcc@....

   spack install foo   ^intel-mkl
   # works as expected

   spack install foo%intel  ^intel-mkl%gcc
   spack install foo%gcc@otherversion  ^intel-mkl%gcc@installedversion
   # also works
   ```
   However, this requires recurring effort from the user to _always_ qualify dependencies, and possibly later to re-identify them when inevitably forgotten.

* Unfortunately, trying to cement, so to speak, a fixed compiler spec for an installed binary package in a ``providers:`` tag in ``packages.yaml`` does _not_ (yet?) work:

  ``` yaml
  packages:
    all:
      providers:
        blas:      [intel-mkl%gcc, ]
        lapack:    [intel-mkl%gcc, ]
        scalapack: [intel-mkl%gcc, ]
  ```
  ```
  $ spack spec hypre~mpi %intel 
  …
  hypre@2.14.0%intel@18.0.2~int64+internal-superlu~mpi+shared arch=linux-centos6-x86_64 
      ^intel-mkl@2018.3.222%intel@18.0.2~ilp64+shared threads=none arch=linux-centos6-x86_64
  ```
  Note how still ``^intel-mkl%intel`` is called for.
